title: GOOD magazine typeface
content:
Anyone recognize the font that GOOD uses for their logo?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801im_/http:/typophile.com/files/goodmagazines_4474.jpg)

Thanks!

Joyce
author: joycie319

comments.content: Logo is custom, but _GOOD_ uses [Vista Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=Vista%20Sans) and [Trade Gothic No. 20 Condensed Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/linotype/trade_gothic_no_20_condensed_bold/) throughout each issue. The look was directed by [Scott Stowell of Open](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801/http:/www.notclosed.com/pages/wemake/work_good.html).
Also, if I remember correctly, [Adsans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotypemachi/adsans/), which is the only misstep in the design.

Logo could be based on [Pakt](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801/http:/www.youworkforthem.com/product.php?sku=T0016). For more options, see also the first section of this post on [extra bold fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontfeed/archives/extra-bold-ultra-black-fonts/).

The logo was hand-drawn by Arnaud Mercier. In the pages we use Vista, Benton, Trade Gothic Bold Condensed, Sabon, and not Adsans but [Doric Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/doric/bold/)--one of my favorite beautifully ugly typefaces--for bold ledes.
To resurrect an old thread, here is a nice look into [Mercier's process of the logo development](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090801/http:/www.area17.com/03_work/good_magazine/01_logos/).

And what about the typeface used for titling in last issue?
